results.title: Now you're talking
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Australian Cinema Series”.
The 30s saw the introduction of the “talkies” and a new era of filmmaking began. This was to decline with World War II. Excerpts from many of the films made during this decade are seen in this video. Please note that the commentary by Leo McKern has been recorded on another channel and may not be heard over the original sound recording. Includes b&w sequences.

results.title: STD's . . . Not just long distance phone calls
results.creator_credit: Wendy Thompson, Sabina Wynn and New South Wales. Dept. of Health
results.brief_description: An entertaining look at the ways in which sexually transmitted diseases are transmitted and how they can (mostly) be cured. Looks at what happens at an STD clinic and encourages the use of condoms to prevent STDs.

results.title: History of Australian Cinema [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Anthony Buckley, Frank Bagnall and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
“History of Australian Cinema Series”.
Three part documentary series about the history of the Austalian Motion Picture industry. “The Pictures That Moved” describes the intense activity in the Australian film industry from the first screening at the Melbourne Opera House in 1896 to the decline of the industry in the early 1920’s. Extracts from productions of particular interest are shown, including “Soldiers of the cross”, “Living Hawthorn”, “The Story of the Kelly gang”, “A Girl of the bush”, “On our selection” and “The Sentimental bloke”, with stills, contemporary press reports and interviews. Shows the technical advances gained, and the exhibition of the national character in a wide range of films. Shows the running of the first filmed Melbourne Cup in 1896 and a finals game of VFL at the Melbourne Cricket Ground between South Melbourne and Carlton. “The Passionate Industry” traces the history of the Australian film industry in the decade 1920-1930. Includes material from fifty newsreels, sixteen feature films and still photographs drawn from many collections. “Now you’re talking” - The 30s saw the introduction of the “talkies” and a new era of filmmaking began. This was to decline with World War II. Excerpts from many of the films made during this decade are seen in this work. Also available on VHS and 16mm [008384], [012586], [012406].

results.title: A Crop of records
results.brief_description: In 1960, Victoria’s wheat growing record was smashed by a bumper harvest. 95% of the wheat was from varieties bred by the Victorian Department of Agriculture including Pinnacle; Insignia; Beacon; and Olympic. Don Rooney, an agronomist in the Wimmera region talks to Victorian farmer Harry Bouchier about his record harvest. We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.

We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.

results.title: The Argentine ant
results.brief_description: This film describes the methods used by State and Municipal authorities and C.S.I.R.O. to eradicate the Argentine Ant in large suburban and city areas. The efforts of individual householders to eradicate the pest have proved unsuccessful. The film shows, in detail, the large scale methods developed by the C.S.I.R.O. which have been used systematically and methodically in attempting to eradicate the pest.

results.title: Stories from the Jewish Community
results.creator_credit: Adriana Gomberg, Idit Benjamin, Alain Herz, Adam Barolsky, Adam Nudelman, Emma Levy, Sheiny New, Jenni Klempfner, Ximena Silberman, Astrid Silberman, ACMI and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
An ACMI digital storytelling workshop creating stories through and about the Australian, Jewish community in partnership with The Jewish Museum of Australia.
These ten personal stories tell of the reasons for emigrating to Australia, whether it be for love or for a better life. These stories are woven with the excitement of new beginnings, the heartache of separation and the challenges of fitting respected traditions in with the new culture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adriana Gomberg, Idit Benjamin, Alain Herz, Adam Barolsky, Adam Nudelman, Emma Levy, Sheiny New, Jenni Klempfner, Ximena Silberman, Astrid Silberman, ACMI and ACMI Digital Storytelling

results.title: Small town girl
results.creator_credit: Emma Levy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Emma Levy leaves the confines of small town life in New Zealand for Melbourne in the hope of connecting with a bigger Jewish community. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Jewish Museum of Australia.

results.title: The Shoemaker
results.creator_credit: Adam Nudelman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Artist Adam Nudelman asks himself why he always paints shoes? Behind these objects lies a story about family and loss and brings him closer to his Jewish heritage. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Jewish Museum of Australia

results.title: Second life
results.creator_credit: Ximena Silberman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ximena migrated to Australia in 2003. To migrate is to be born again. While enjoying her new life in Australia, she looks back at the friendships and life she left behind in Buenos Aires. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Jewish Museum of Australia
